title: Let's talk about maps
body:
**WARNING 1:** I'm sorry but I'm very bad editing images fast and I'm very excited right now with the new things to wait. With this said, let's go. 

So you'll probably know it by now (at least if you are a lore fanatic as crazy for the map as me) but Riot is sending wooden pieces of the map to some of the loremaster youtubers out there:

For now we have 2 pieces: 

* One for Necrit: https://twitter.com/Necrit94/status/1020283431639568384
 
* One for Nero Wolf: https://www.facebook.com/NeroWolf66/posts/1845212495518111

Necrit's one seems to be Ionia but I don't think we can talk too much about that for now because we don't have a lot of references... but what about the other one? 

NeroWolf's one is veeeery interesting 

**WARNING 2:** First time I post images so I'm not sure if i'm doing it well. 

Why? Because [**we already knew some things**](https://na.leagueoflegends.com/en/featured/piltover/medarda-heirloom) about parts of this map. 

Look at this. 
https://i.imgur.com/uhhnPO1.jpg

https://i.imgur.com/O3qN4VR.jpg

https://i.imgur.com/aKUB3Pi.jpg

Seems clear now? 

If not look at this 

https://i.imgur.com/HXDipEb.jpg

So now we know how does** the eastern side of the Southern Continent** looks like.

_Can I go a bit further? Maybe? _
{{sticker:sg-miss-fortune}} 
**Everything from here is just pure speculation** that may have sense in the future or may not have it at all 

So... Let's do this. 

From the icon map + the Medarda's map we can see this: 

https://i.imgur.com/A2i0Yng.jpg

Now we know that all the coast seems to be a bit less than the total width of the Southern Continent (from East to West) 

Medarda's ships take (according to the map)** around 18 - 20 days to cross from Kalamanda in the West to Mudtown in the East. **
But... how fast a merchant ship of Pilltover can be? We don't know. 
But we know how fast were the ships of [the Portugal and Spanish trade empires in the XV - XVI centuries ](http://www-labs.iro.umontreal.ca/~vaucher/History/Ships_Discovery/)

The average was 4 knots for 90-100 miles in a day. Maybe we can take even 5 knots and 120 miles. So what happens if you take that 120 miles a day and you translate that into kilometers?

You have between 3500 and 4000 kilometers and that 's close to the Mediterranean Sea width. So we can say it: Southern Continent at least in it's north side is almost the same size as Northern Africa.

So Shurima Empire in it's apogee was big. I do not want to speculate a lot here without knowing more about the real dimensons of the Southern continent but Shuriman Empire may have been [around the maximum size of the Roman Empire ](https://visualunit.files.wordpress.com/2016/01/roman_empire.png)

What do you think about this? Seems promising for me. 

Thanks @Riot! But we want more. We want everything!

Interesting. That's definetly something new. I have at least two theories but I need an image with better quality for the tracking. **Thanks for the update!**

The only real flaw I can find in the logic is that Piltover ships are equivalent to any pre-industrial civilization.  

Frankly the level of technological might Piltover has shown rivals and in some ways eclipses the technology of the mid-20th century. Some of it is better than our modern day standards. 

You could, in theory, be off by 16 knots or more. 

In any case great post.

I have the same doubts. I decided about my example according to 2 factors:

1) **Pilltover is a tech mistery with great gaps **between the different scientific fields (I mean Caitlyn is a thing but what about Camille. A full cyborg. We can't reach that in the 21st century) so I prefered to go with the lower expectation (around a century above the others) and not with the biggest (maybe half a milennia?). Also I think Pilltover is closer to become Steampunk than Cyberpunk. 

2) **The amount of trade ports**. If we go with the fastest ships in mind the continent would be enormous and only the important trade ports appear in the Medarda's map and that does not seem to be the case.

> [{quoted}](name=Loborcs,realm=EUW,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=K4KqjyuU,comment-id=00040000,timestamp=2018-07-20T23:20:56.102+0000)
>
> I have the same doubts. I decided about my example according to 2 factors:

There's also the factor that the map is an heirloom, and, while some things have been crossed out, the time-to-travel has *not*. This indicates that it is likely a family heirloom passed from generation to generation, and so likely matches older ship technology rather than newer -- technology still in use, or the times would have been updated. Additionally, we have never seen any sort of tech-enhanced ship in any of the Bilgewater art, and Bilgewater is a place one would expect to see such a thing if it were at all common, as it would make an amazing prize.

My suspicion is that -- while such a ship likely does exist -- they are highly expensive, few, and extremely far between. The sort of thing a Zaunite chem-baron might have one of, for example, rather than the sort of thing a trade family would own. Why have one super fancy ship when, for the same price, you could buy six normal ships and expand your reach and cargo capacity more?

Caitlyn is the one that made me bring up the mid-20th century.  I think we can agree she's the lowest tier of the Piltover tech champions.  i mean, technically Janna is Piltover now.  But she's magic god thing.  So whatever.

But Caitlyn is using a rifled sniper with a three lens magnifying scope.  That's strictly WWII tech.  

Which can probably just be explained away with the good old fashion: writers have no sense of scale.  But, I just thought I'd throw that out there.
